column2: Lunar Module Pilot Fred Haise is shown relaxing in one of the leather recliners provided for the crewmembers during the suiting up. The dark 'cap' on the left side of his helmet is a contingency feeding port
column5: a vent through which a straw can be pushed in so that the astronaut can consume drinks even while wearing the suit, and in depressurized conditions. This feature was to ensure that the crew could be hydrated and fed in the case of the spacecraft losing cabin pressure and forcing them to make the return trip wearing their suits.

S-IVB Auxiliary Propulsion System diagram
The two APS units can be used for three-axis control of the S-IVB/Apollo stack while in orbit. The ullage thrusters are used to settle the fuel before engine burns.

Each APS thruster uses hypergolic fuels that explode on contact, and helium for pressurization. The interior of the rocket engine is lined with an ablative material that cools the thruster via controlled burning off.
NASA artist's concept of the Apollo 8 S-IVB/Apollo stack soon after Translunar Injection. This work gives a good idea of what the stack looked like with the first and second stages gone.

DPS pressurization from the LM 2-hour Contingency Checklist, pages 14 and 15

To pressurize the DPS, they must select MASTER ARM to enable the pyrotechnics and then turn the associated switches. Pyrotechnic isolation valves are used to open the piping that will transport the propellant, the oxidizer, and the Helium used to pressurize the system. This way, all three will remain contained until they are required to be used, and are hence protected against the hardships of the launch and the translunar coast.

Applying power to the pyrotechnic device sends an electric charge to the detonator. The small explosive device createst a burst of mechanical energy which is used to drive a piston through the closed off propellant and helium lines. It shears the closure and puts the piston port into place, which allows the liquids and gasses to pass through into the system.

They are taking turns wearing the 'Snoopy cap' communications headset. Currently only one of them is hooked up to the LMP's audio panel. This is why the latest words we heard from the ship were one-sided with Jack's portion being captured by the mic.
Window 1 is on the left side of the spacecraft. Looking backwards from it, the area Fred specifies is somewhere along what to him looks like the 'top' side of the SM.

Apollo 12 photograph shows the Passive Seismic Detector deployed on the Lunar Surface, by Pete Conrad and Alan Bean. This is the instrument that is now providing NASA with data on the interior of the Moon thanks to the impact of the SIV-B.
Lovell captured on 16mm DAC film in the LM. Via JSC.

Deke Slayton shows off the adapter prototype.

Howard Tindall, observing the filter in the above picture, was also involved in producing the checklists needed for the crew's safe return. Known as a particularly capable engineer besides his great talent in organization, he had among other things ensured the timely production of the Apollo computer software. Having him onboard for Apollo 13's rescue was no surprise. Handwritten notes by Gene Kranz.
Lithium Hydroxide canister.

The LCG is the Liquid Cooled Garment, special underwear with water piping in it to keep moonwalkers from overheating inside their suits. For now, they are only using the plastic bags they come packed in for the trip.
Jim holding a checklist, showing off the size and shape as well as the ring binders. 16mm film capture. Via NARA.

Crossection of a Lithium Hydroxide canister. The canisters are constructed of aluminum with a Teflon coating. They contain the aforementioned chemical to scrub carbon dioxide from the cabin atmosphere, a layer of activated charcoal, and a felt filter for catching particles while air flows through the canister. Apollo ECS training material. NASA.

Jack Swigert, the canister adapter, and Jim Lovell (his hands), photo taken by Fred Haise. The setup suggets that they are in the process of constructing the adapter but this is actually a later moment, with Swigert and Lovell busy with their water supply hoses instead. No photos or movie film footage are known to exist of the actual construction process, considering how busy the crew was at the time. A copy of their Flight Plan and other Flight Data File materials are behind the retaining bar next to Jack's head level. It is perhaps here they took the covers from, for the cardboard parts of the adapter.
The finished adapter. The various taping patterns are well visible.

Apollo crewman scissors. This pair was used by Dave Scott during Apollo 9. Note the patch of Velcro on the hinge for attaching the scissors to the spacecraft surfaces. Photo from the personal collection of Steve Jurvetson, and used with his permission.
Tom Stafford in Mission Control. 16mm NASA film capture. Via NARA.
Page 1 of the hand-annotated and marked altered Launch Checklist, now known as Baseline Checklist.
Diagram of the CM window shades.

Diagram of the hose positions, presented to the Flight Director. From Flight Log.
Photograph AS-13-02-29981, interior of the docking tunnel. Color correction by David Woods.

The biomedical instrumentation harness.The biomedical system contains several signal conditioner boxes on a belt worn around the waist. The previously discussed component is the main box which receives power from the communications cable and converts it to 5 volts DC, hence producing heat.
The prototype lithium hydroxide canister adapter in the 11-foot vacuum chamber, hooked up to a simulated LM ECS installation.

Avco Corporation engineers filling the heat shield honeycomb orifices with phenolic resin from caulking guns.
Jim and Fred viewed in the LM cockpit from the docking tunnel section. 16mm film capture.
AOT detents. Number 2 is facing directly forward. From the LM Guidance System Operations Plan. MIT/Draper Labs.
The AGS Data Entry and Display Assembly. By keying in ADDRESS 470, they can display the delta-V produced by the engine during the course correction burn.
Diagram of the Commander's window in the LM, with the Crewman Optical Alignment Sight in position.
How Earth would appear through the COAS for the midcourse correction burn.
Lunar Module water control panel, including the suit temp selection.
Lunar Module suit circuit.
LM engine controls at the bottom of Commander's panel. Scan via heroicrelics.org.
Guarded LM engine manual START button.
LM RCS geometry. The two fuel and control systems are labeled as A and B, respectively, allowing each system to provide minimum three-axis control.
Apollo 13 Flight Plan page 3-77
Milton Windler and Gerry Griffin in Mission Control. 16mm film capture. NASA/NARA
Flight Director Milton Windler photographed at his station in Mission Control.
Explosive Devices switches, including the fuel and oxidizer vents, on Panel 8 in the LM. Original scan courtesies of heroicrelics.org.
Vents in the Descent Stage of the Apollo 14 LM Antares. Photo and editing courtesies of Frank O'Brien.

The burst disk, one of the most talked about components of the LM during the mission. There are actually two of them inside the device, each set to be burst by a a spring-loaded punch when the pressure rises to its set level.

Battery status displays on LM Panel 14. The BAT FAULT light comes on if a malfunction state is detected in any of the batteries. To check the batteries, the rotating POWER/TEMP MON switch is moved through each position to view the volts and amps on the gauges, and to see whether the fault indicator light comes on. It has now been illuminated upon Fred selecting Battery 2. Original scan via heroicrelics.org.
Fred Haise seen floating 'down' the docking tunnel and into the LM. Onboard 16 mm film. JSC.

Exploded view of the OPS, or the Oxygen Purge System. It is a relatively simple device, consisting of two oxygen spheres that contain a total of 5. pounds of gaseous oxygen at the extremely high pressure of 6,950 psia. A small regulator unit and a self-contained electric heater complete the system. It supplies oxygen for approximately 30 minutes, allowing an astronaut with a malfunctioning PLSS backpack to return to the LM. Their other envisioned use would be for transferring between the LM and the CM should there be a need for an emergency EVA due to inability to dock or repressurize the LM after their moonwalk.
Lousma suggests that they can produce a rough attitude reference by once again lining up the COAS with the Earth terminator, to align the AGS into a known body reference.
The AGS can be programmed to establish its attitude reference along the LM body axes, which means that they correspond to the physical axes of the spacecraft, as detailed in the diagram.
LM battery display. Original scan via heroicrelics.org

Diagram of the various ways to determine the three axes of motion onboard the Command Module. The angles detected by the IMU are off-set from the physical axes due to the positioning of the IMU, and are taken into account. The optics' placement and angles are also computed into the system when using star and other sightings for aligning the platform.

column2: Data documents for the Apollo program contain figures for many standard and non-standard values, including the approximate time that it should take for the crew to don their space suits. 9 minutes, 17 seconds is apparently the fastest one has been put on in zero-G. During normal operations, each crewmember is allocated 20 minutes to put on their suit
column5: doing it one by one, presumably due to the wriggle room required. Hence the Flight Plan always has a one-hour block for all three to suit up, each in turn.
Jack with the checklist. 16mm onboard film capture.

Flow chart of the Command Module Electric Power System. To charge the battery A for now, they need to set up the circuit breakers and switches so that electric current may flow from the LM Umbilical to DC MAIN BUS B. From, there, the LM battery current is connected to the battery charger through Main Bus B for the DC power, and to one of the inverters to supply AC power to the charger. The battery A itself is connected to the system through the Battery Bus. The charge procedure is normal besides the source of the electric power coming into the charger, which would normally be supplied by the fuel cells.

During re-entry, the center of gravity in the Command Module is deliberately off-set so that the capsule attempts to maintain a lopsided attitude. This allows them to modify the relationship of the drag (how much the atmosphere is slowing them d own) and the lift (how much their hull, acting as a wing, is working to keep them flying instead of plummeting down.) To maintain this position, the weight onboard is unevenly distributed.
LM Ascent Battery switches. Original scan via heroicrelics.org

LM comms control panel. They turn on the power amplifier so as to able to consistently transmit the high bit rate telemetry and use the normal voice on the S-Band. Mission Control wants the high bit rate so that they can monitor the batteries during the beginning of the power transfer procedure. Original scan via heroicrelics.org

Command module batteries arrangement. Three silver-zinc rechargable 40-amp batteries are located at the bottom of the CM, sandwiched between the three AC inverters and control equipment. The two PYRO batteries (A and B) are located there as well and provide a separate source of power for the sequential systems. A gas line is connected to each of the battery containers in order to vent out any hydrogen gases the batteries might produce.
One iteration of the infamous towing bill. Via NASA History Office.

Command Module DC Bus power displays, which are also used to monitor the battery charge. The amperage of the battery charge is read from the special inner scale running from 0 to 5 amps. Original scan via heroicrelics.org.

It does not come as a surprise that the astronauts were concerned about their bowel habits, considering the onboard facilities consisted of a plastic bag taped into place for use. The messy and unpleasant procedure would take at least 45 minutes.

Deke Slayton filmed at the news conference. The journalists got to face a somewhat cranky, cigarillo-smoking Director Slayton who dodged their questions and kept saying that everything was proceeding according to the plan.

Diagram of the lunar overshoe. They are mostly made of Beta cloth with multiple layers of Mylar and Kapton for micrometeroid and thermal insulation. They were designed to be slipped over the space suit boots to protect them from abrasion and thermal differences while on the lunar surface.
This film shows Fred sleeping strapped to the Commander's station in the LM. This view has made its way into many Apollo 13 documentaries and books as well.16 mm film capture. JSC
Jim Lovell at the LMP's station, Jack Swigert sleeping. 16mm capture. JSC

The Suit Circuit Relief valve protects the suit circuit against overpressurization by allowing excess pressure to bleed into the cabin. In AUTO mode, the valve opens automatically to release pressure. For now, they want it in the CLOSE position to ensure that a sufficient pressure is maintained in the suit circuit to keep their atmosphere circulating properly despite the CM lithium hydroxide canister adapter in place on the circuit.
The classic photo AS13-629004 shows the position of the canister adapter directly in front of the Suit Circuit Relief valve. Someone must've bumped at the canister, accidentally operating the valve.
Command Module RCS.
Automated SM Separation Sequence
Example page from the stowage plan in the Launch Checklist.
Command Module stowage plan.
Diagram of the R-9 compartment, or the waste stowage. The compartment was airtight and could be vented to space to prevent unpleasant smells from entering the cabin.
Jack in the Commander's position in the LM. The ISA is to his left in this in-flight 16mm film frame from NASA.
Inflight 16mm film caption of the jettison bag in use in the LM. NASA/NARA.
The stowage plan changes for Apollo 13 on a typed page, from the Flight Director's Log.
Throughout the LM phase of the return, the crew has had one of them use the comm carrier in turn.
This Systems Handbook diagram shows the backside of the Main Display Console, with the various cable installations.

column2: A table of ECS-related temperature and pressure values attached to the Flight Director's Log shows the trend that Vance mentions here, comparing these values at three points
column5: around the time the CM's telemetry system was being turned off, and the two telemetry passes done since to check up on the ship.
EECOM John Aaron photographed in Mission Control during the crisis.
Hasselblad 70mm electric camera and accessories.
Maurer 16mm film camera and accessories.
Diagram of the Command Module potable (drinking) water tank. It was located in the aft compartment of the spacecraft, outside the pressure hull.
The Command Module orientation at Entry REFSMMAT.
Ken Mattingly at the CapCom station in Mission Control.

CM Panel 5. The rotating rheostats are used to turn on the interior lighting. Note the stoppers in the NUMERICS and INTEGRAL lighting that prevent them from being turned to full OFF position. Scan via heroicrelics.org
Panel 100. These rheostats are used to turn on the Lower Equipment Bay lights. The same panel contains the guarded switch to turn the IMU power on and off.
Panel 250. These circuit breakers are used to connect the pyro batteries and the Command Module main batteries to the power buses.
CSM RCS preheat sequence
The Command Module RCS jet arrangement.
The RESET/OFF switches on Panel 3 are used to reset the undercurrent alarms in the main buses. Original scan via heroicrelics.org.

column2: Step 39 is a check of the two small pyro batteries that supply electric charge to the sequential systems. Once the crewman verifies that the breakers are closed, they will then check their voltage from the DC voltage indicator on Panel 3
column5: the same one they've been using to check their battery charge status as of late. If the voltage is not within nominal limits, the pyro battery will be taken off the line and instead they will tie the battery buses in to provide sequential power from the main batteries instead.
The two pyro batteries are located in the Lower Equipment Bay, adjacent to the main batteries and the AC inverters and the battery charger. They supply 0.75 amp hours each, and are not recharged.

The sequential system is enabled once again, this time so that explosive isolation valves in the CM RCS can be fired to open the propellant feed lines. After a quick pressure check using a switch to change the RCS displays to show the status of the Command Module System instead of the Service Module RCS system, the sequential systems are secured again.
IMU heater breakers on panel 5. Scan via heroicrelics.org

Step 4 accomplishes the previously mentioned test firing of the Command Module RCS jets. The test will be performed with the spacecraft control mode set to Stabilization Control System, and using the Rotational Hand Controller for the firing commands.
Panel 225 in the Command Module has circuit breakers that supply power to the communications equipment.
Bottom of Panel 3 contains the majority of the radio system control switches. Original scan via heroicrelics.org.

Entry Monitoring System. During reentry, it will be used to display various parameters, including the range to go and a Mylar film strip window that tracks their atmospheric trajectory. Scan via heroicrelics.org
Next follows a test of the various components of the EMS accessible via the rotating mode selection knob on the panel.

After turning on the LOGIC POWER and powering up the FDAI 8-balls, the CMC will be set to FREE, meaning that the computer will not attempt to sense or control the spacecraft attitude. Afterwards, it is a matter of flicking the power switch and waiting for 90 seconds for the IMU platform to come back up. the NO ATT warning light going out on the DSKY is their cue that the platform is ready to be set up.
The optics powerful consists of hitting the power switch and ensuring that the optics are zeroed ie. placed into their neutral position.
Page 7-1 from the Command Module Guidance and Navigation checklist offers the quick reference to how to set the REFSMMAT and drift flags.
GN Checklist page 2-4.
16mm DAC film caption from Apollo 8 showing then-CMP Jim Lovell at the optics station.
At this point, they will configure the EMS to display the parameters for their planned entry.
Entry checklist page 2-2
Entry Checklist page E1-1, with modifications.
Entry Checklist page E1-2, with modifications.
Entry Checklist page E1-3, with modifications.
Entry Checklist page E1-4, with modifications.
Entry Checklist page 2-1, with modifications.
Entry Checklist page 2-2, with modifications.
Entry Checklist page 2-3, with modifications.
Entry Checklist page 2-5, with modifications.
CM GC Checklist, page 2-1, with modifications.
CM GC Checklist, page 2-2, with modifications.
CM GC Checklist, page 2-4, with modifications.
LM ascent stage water system consists of two nitrogen-pressurized spherical tanks located in compartments that flank the docking tunnel and the hatch.
LM water controls. They're located behind LMP's station. The procedure for changing the water tank being used is simple enough.
This page from the Apollo 11 Systems Checklist is equal to the page from Jack's own checklist, and shows the procedure for the hatch integrity check.
Orientation of the CSM and LM during docking operations.
Suit circuit and LiOH canister selection levers. It appears that they have once again bumped at the valve or at the oxygen hoses, causing the valve to go out of place.

The double paned LM windows have an electric heater installed into them. They consume a lot of power and as a result would produce plentiful heat as well. The crew does not dare to turn them on, however, due to them being practically frozen. The sudden change in temperature might crack the pane.
View through the AOT reticle.

The LM's RCS propellant supply is growing limited, and a careful budget was planned for the remainer of the mission. This is another reason why Jack Lousma keeps repeatedly commenting about saving gas.

Steps 5 and 6 on the LM Contingency Activation Checklist, page 8. The 2-hour activation. The REFSMMAT and drift flags are set as valid to tell the computer they know the attitude of the IMU, and that they have applied the drift compensation to the gyroscopes.

column2: P52 IMU Realign, Step 7. To tell the computer that they are using the Sun and the Moon for navigational sightings, Jack is giving Fred the codes used for VERB 01 NOUN 70 on Step 7. The first digit
column5: 2- implies the position of the AOT, this time pointing forward. The last two digits are the code from the Apollo star list. The sun's code is 46 and the Moon is 50.
Rapid IMU Realign procedure on page 7-1 on the G&C checklist.
Jack Swigert holding the Entry Checklist. A 16mm film capture from the mission. NASA/JSC
Astronauts monitoring the mission. Although taken earlier, it shows most of the same crowd that had gathered for the moment as well.
Apollo Command Module medical kit.
Pyrotechnic separation control switches on the bottom of Panel 2 on the MDC. Original scan via heroicrelics.org.
Diagram of the Service Module separation.
Command Module/Service Module electric interrupter.
Service Module Umbilical
Command/Service Module tension ties.
The newly separated Service Module floating away. This color image shows the missing panel and the now released SM/CM umbilical, on the top.

The damage inside sector 4 is evident. The hull panel is almost entirely gone, and although the fuel cells can be seen on their installed positions, the section with the cryogenics tanks and their support equipment is a jumble of jagged metal and broken insulation.

While the crew was only able to take a glimpse and describe what they saw, the photographs they took were used to analyse the total extent of the damage. The place of the O<sub>2</sub> Tank 2 is empty. Damage is visible to the High Gain Antenna and the SPS engine nozzle as well.
The skin of the Command Module and the Service Module shine in sunlight. The now distant Moon is seen as a bright spot as well.

Drawing of the Service Module based on the photographs. From the Investigation Report. Electric cables and pieces of insulation spew out of the damaged Service Module. While the fuel cells can be identified, the space that should be occupied by the number 2 oxygen tank is empty. The damage to the high gain antenna is very much evident too, with one of the horns visibly twisted from the bay 4 panel hitting it.

Command Module window markings, useful for reentry orientation. They will be used to sight the Moon at the hatch window at a specific time and orientation, as a quick reference to them being at the proper position.
Map of the Primary Recovery Area, with the gathered forces.
The optical path inside the Scanning Telescope.
Entry REFSMMAT.
AS13-59-8484. Jim in the Lunar Module. What it would have looked like in Aquarius during these final moments of its occupancy.
LM Attitude Control switches. Jim sets up AGS ATTITUDE HOLD with a wide deadband as one of his last acts in the LM. Scan via heroicrelics.org
The 02 FLOW HIGH warning indicator.
Joe's suggestion is that the regulator is simply allowing slightly more oxygen into the cabin than expected, and is not a cause of real worry.
BMAG controls at Panel 7. They're powering up the BMAGs to provide a backup attitude reference in case the IMU fails. Scan via heroicrelics.org
BMAG 1 TEMP caution light illuminated. They decide to press on either way.

The last photographed glimpse of Aquarius from the CM window. The Reseau plate-equipped Hasselblad with a 70mm lense was used for the final photos of the LM, as indicated by the crosses well visible against the shiny LM skin. Notice the separated docking ring visible, having been pyrotechnically broken off the Command Module.
Diagram of the Lunar module separation.

Diagram of the long range plane rescue plan. The Command Module can signal its position via a radio beacon, a dye marker, and a flashing strobe light. The search plane can drop a bundle of equipment attached to a long floating rope the Command Module crew can snatch using a hook stowed onboard.
Observation of the Moon on their hatch window has been successful.
Astronauts have gathered around the CapCom station. Ken Mattingly, John Young, Tom Stafford, Deke Slayton and CapCom Joe Kerwin. NASA 16 film capture. NASA/NARA.
The Entry Monitoring System at the Main Display Console. Scan via heroicrelics.org
The switches for manually starting the EMS. Scan via heroicrelics.org
An artist's imagined view of the Command Module entering Earth atmosphere.
The Entry Shockwave and drag to lift ratio.
Command Module Reentry Aerodynamics
Various entry corridor states and the associated EMS displays.
Entry Monitoring System Scroll pattern
Astronauts await the splashdown. NASA 16 mm film capture. Via NARA.
ARIA aircraft, with an S-band antenna system on the oversized nosecone.
A tense Joe Kerwin awaits radio contact, or a visual on the CM.
Exterior view of the Command Module.
Earth Landing System equipment, under the apex cover.
Drogue sequence.
Mission Control erupts in joy.
The Command Module nearing splashdown.
The splashdown viewed on the TV from the recovery helicopter.
Jubilant Flight Controllers in Mission Control.
The exact moment of splashdown photographed. The parachutes are already starting to deflate.
The Command Module in the water, moments after splashdown. TV capture.
All clear so far!
Apollo rescue swimmer hand signals.
The still deflated flotation collar being attached to the Command Module. TV capture.
Swimmers are about to attach the newly inflated raft to the flotation collar in front of the hatch.
The egress raft is ready and the diver is looking into the Command Module
TV capture shows the crewmen being helped out of the Command Module by rescue swimmers.
The rescue net is received at the egress raft. The Apollo crewmen are ready to go up.
Fred Haise being hoisted up.
Jack Swigert going up.
Jack Swigert hoisted to the rescue chopper.
The rescue net being moved to the egress raft for Jim Lovell. The Captain leaves last.
The rescue helicopter has landed, and a red carpet is being rolled out for the crew.
A black and white TV image captures the cheering Mission Control, including Ken Mattingly.
Lovell, Swigert and Haise greet the crew of Iwo Jima from the helicopter steps.
The exact moment the picture above was taken, as seen in Mission Control.
Eager officials and crew meet the astronauts as they walk along the red carpet to greet the Commanding Officer of the carrier.
Celebratory cigars in Mission Control. Live TV from the Iwo Jima is projected on the big screen.
The crew greeted by commanding officers of the USS Iwo Jima and the recovery task force.
Photograph of the prayer for the safe return of the crew. Ship's Chaplain, Commander Philip E. Jerauld officiating.
Video capture of the prayer, from the TV stream.
One of the many photos of the crew posing on the deck.
The Odyssey is hoisted down to the deck of the Iwo Jima and onto the CM Dolly.
Diagram of external points of interest and inspection from the Recovery Manual.
The crew of Apollo 13 receiving a phone call from President Nixon while in sickbay.
A banquet held for the crew onboard the Iwo Jima.
President Nixon at the Manned Spaceflight Center, Houston.
Richard Nixon poses with the crew of Apollo 13, having bestowed presidential honors on them.
The Medal of Freedom article.
Lei'd crew of Apollo 13, feted by people in Hawaii.
Lovell, Haise and Swigert during the Technical Crew Debriefing. Although Deke Slayton conducted the interviews, here they have been joined by none other than Wehrner von Braun.
The complex organization of the Review Board.
Slow motion photography shows the separation of the simulated Service Module panel due to tank explosion.
The basic arrangement of the Apollo Service Module.
Manual assembly of the internal electric components of the tank.
Components of the O<sub>2</sub> tank.
Installation of the equipment into the Service Module, including the hoist machinery used to remove the oxygen shelf from Bay 4.
O<sub>2</sub> Tank 2, installed onboard the Service Module that would fly as Apollo 13.
Giant thermos used for transporting liquid oxygen to the launch service tower.
Crew of Apollo 13 boards the Command Module for the Countdown Demonstration Test, assisted by Pad Leader Guenther Wendt.
Laboratory testing reproduced the thermostat meltdown under the excess current.
Schematic diagram of the thermostat breaker.
Ground Support Equipment panel used to supply electric power to the spacecraft.
A diagram of the complex piping inside the oxygen tank assembly.
Insulation and wiring burns in 100% oxygen during an engineering test to simulate the tank conditions.
Improved cryogenic oxygen tank for Apollo 14 and subsequent missions.
Diagram showing the CSM improvements and alterations after Apollo 13.
New controls in the MDC, with faculties for monitoring the new O2 tank. Fan switches have been removed.
Diagram of the refit oxygen system for Apollo 14 and subsequent missions.
Commander Alan Shepard performing lunar geology at Fra Mauro.
The Enterprise seconds after release from the Shuttle Carrier Aircraft.
Ken Mattingly in his space shuttle regalia, with pilot Hank Hartsfield for STS-4 crew portrait.
Commander John Young and Pilot Bob Crippen in their STS-1 crew photo.
The first US space station, Skylab, photographed on Earth orbit in 1973. One solar panel is missing, and a gold-colored tarp replaced the damaged thermal shield.
Science Pilot Joe Kerwin performs a dental exam on his Commander Pete Conrad onboard the Skylab.

column2: Pilot Jack Lousma enjoys one of the luxuries of Skylab unimaginable to earlier Apollo astronauts
column5: a shower! One of the most famous Skylab photos.
CMP Vance Brand gives a thumbs up during the last Apollo flight, the ASTP, in 1975.
Deke Slayton slides through the Docking module during ASTP, in 1975.
Artist impression of the Apollo and Souyz spacecraft docking in orbit.
